content.raw:
The sdf parser is now a library: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat that also depends on https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math.

sdformat is still using boost, mostly the boost::filesystem
content.html:
The sdf parser is now a library: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat that also depends on https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math.

sdformat is still using boost, mostly the boost::filesystem

content.raw:
When I first wanted to parse sdf in dart, it seemed the sdf parsing code is fully integrated with gazebo so couldn't be used separately (maybe I'm wrong). If there is an official sdf parser, we definitely would like to use it.

Also, removing the boost dependency sounds good to us since dart is already using C++11.
content.html:
When I first wanted to parse sdf in dart, it seemed the sdf parsing code is fully integrated with gazebo so couldn't be used separately (maybe I'm wrong). If there is an official sdf parser, we definitely would like to use it.

Also, removing the boost dependency sounds good to us since dart is already using C++11.

content.raw: Compatiblity. If the project already requires C++11, then it is a perfectly fine option. There are too many Bullet users (and platforms/out-of-date compilers) that didn't switch to C++11 yet, and I prefer to maintain compatibility. By the way, the ROS URDF parser was using BOOST just for 3 small features, so it was trivially to remove BOOST use. I wonder how heavy the use of BOOST/C++11 features are in the SDF parser? You could wrap the C++11-only features such as shared pointer etc in some interfaces?
content.html: Compatiblity. If the project already requires C++11, then it is a perfectly fine option. There are too many Bullet users (and platforms/out-of-date compilers) that didn't switch to C++11 yet, and I prefer to maintain compatibility. By the way, the ROS URDF parser was using BOOST just for 3 small features, so it was trivially to remove BOOST use. I wonder how heavy the use of BOOST/C++11 features are in the SDF parser? You could wrap the C++11-only features such as shared pointer etc in some interfaces?

content.raw: Thanks for the info. We are working on removing the boost dependency. However, this comes with the need to use c++11. This seems like a good tradeoff since c++11 is an officially approved standard. Can you say why c++11 is not a good option?
content.html: Thanks for the info. We are working on removing the boost dependency. However, this comes with the need to use c++11. This seems like a good tradeoff since c++11 is an officially approved standard. Can you say why c++11 is not a good option?

content.raw: Yes, I hope to find time to implement a SDF parser at some stage (I'm reasonably happy with the Bullet urdf loader by the way). It would be great if there was a zero-dependency SDF library in c++2003. So no boost, no c++11 etc. One exception would be a dependency on tinyxml, it is tiny and harmless.
content.html: Yes, I hope to find time to implement a SDF parser at some stage (I'm reasonably happy with the Bullet urdf loader by the way). It would be great if there was a zero-dependency SDF library in c++2003. So no boost, no c++11 etc. One exception would be a dependency on tinyxml, it is tiny and harmless.

content.raw:
It's not mandatory that link 3 define a `l3frame` with respect to the `l3j2frame`. This example just shows how someone might use frames. The user is free to setup their own frame structure as they desire. This of course can be setup incorrectly, but so can any system of frames.

This approach is more flexible than our current system, and does make it easier to setup a series of links. They can specify a series of links in a tree structure, or use the hierarchy that gazebo currently uses, or some combination. I am assuming we will create tutorials and documentation for users. Ideally there will also be GUI tools so that a person does not have to manually create or edit SDF.
content.html:
It's not mandatory that link 3 define a l3frame with respect to the l3j2frame. This example just shows how someone might use frames. The user is free to setup their own frame structure as they desire. This of course can be setup incorrectly, but so can any system of frames.

This approach is more flexible than our current system, and does make it easier to setup a series of links. They can specify a series of links in a tree structure, or use the hierarchy that gazebo currently uses, or some combination. I am assuming we will create tutorials and documentation for users. Ideally there will also be GUI tools so that a person does not have to manually create or edit SDF.

content.raw:
cc: @jespersmith @dljsjr @jlee02 

I'm not sure why they wrote their own parser. I've cc'd them here. I know that @erwincoumans has been hesitant to use sdformat due to its boost dependency.
content.html:
cc: @jespersmith @dljsjr @jlee02

I'm not sure why they wrote their own parser. I've cc'd them here. I know that @erwincoumans has been hesitant to use sdformat due to its boost dependency.

content.raw:
Looking at this, something doesn't feel intuitive or flexible enough. The fact that you must, within link 3, define its own frame `l3frame` with respect to `l3j2frame` means the user must know that joint 2 frame will be closer to the root of the model than joint 3. If the user by any chance decides to flip link 3 to have `l3j2frame` attach to joint 3 and `l3j3frame` attach to joint 2, they have to recalculate all link 3 frames by hand because now the "base" of the link is `l3j3frame`. At least as far as I understand it, adding reference frames was supposed to make this sort of thing easier...

**Basically, I'd like to define all frames inside a link with respect to the link frame and don't need to change it according to the way the link is attached.**

I haven't thought this through yet, but one way of doing this might be by rethinking joints. Currently a joint pose is always specified with respect to the child link. This design so far suggests loosening this and allowing you to specify another frame within a link, which is nice. But this only fixes one half of the problem. The joint connects 2 links, so it would be nice if it connected 2 random frames. Something like this pseudo-SDF:

~~~
<model>
  <link name="link1">
    <frame name ="link1_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_A" pose_frame="link1_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_B" pose_frame="link1_origin" />
  </link>
  <link name="link2">
    <frame name ="link2_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_A" pose_frame="link2_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_B" pose_frame="link2_origin" />
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <parent>link1::attachment_A</parent>
    <child>link2::attachment_B</child>
    <pose frame="link2::attachment_B" />
  </joint>
</model>
~~~

Again, I haven't thought this through. But I imagine that on the physics side, the joint parent and child would still be links. But when parsing poses, the links' internal frames would be used.
content.html:
Looking at this, something doesn't feel intuitive or flexible enough. The fact that you must, within link 3, define its own frame l3frame with respect to l3j2frame means the user must know that joint 2 frame will be closer to the root of the model than joint 3. If the user by any chance decides to flip link 3 to have l3j2frame attach to joint 3 and l3j3frame attach to joint 2, they have to recalculate all link 3 frames by hand because now the "base" of the link is l3j3frame. At least as far as I understand it, adding reference frames was supposed to make this sort of thing easier...

Basically, I'd like to define all frames inside a link with respect to the link frame and don't need to change it according to the way the link is attached.

I haven't thought this through yet, but one way of doing this might be by rethinking joints. Currently a joint pose is always specified with respect to the child link. This design so far suggests loosening this and allowing you to specify another frame within a link, which is nice. But this only fixes one half of the problem. The joint connects 2 links, so it would be nice if it connected 2 random frames. Something like this pseudo-SDF:

<model>
  <link name="link1">
    <frame name ="link1_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_A" pose_frame="link1_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_B" pose_frame="link1_origin" />
  </link>
  <link name="link2">
    <frame name ="link2_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_A" pose_frame="link2_origin" />
    <frame name ="attachment_B" pose_frame="link2_origin" />
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <parent>link1::attachment_A</parent>
    <child>link2::attachment_B</child>
    <pose frame="link2::attachment_B" />
  </joint>
</model>

Again, I haven't thought this through. But I imagine that on the physics side, the joint parent and child would still be links. But when parsing poses, the links' internal frames would be used.

I agree that we don't want something overly complex. We also need something that is flexible and capable of representing tree and graph structures.

The approach proposed here should be relatively easy to implement. Instead of implicit frames, which we currently have, every frame is explicit. We'll also have example code, and tutorials.

@scpeters, do you know why IHMC and dartsim implement their own parser? We might be able to improve libsdformat to be more attractive to them.

content.raw:
This is a valid concern.
I think it might be possible to keep the implementation simpler while keeping important functionality:
For example, we could:

* confine frames to a single link, without the possibility of specifying a parent.
* when declaring a pose, limit the use of frames to the current link (or sibling), instead of arbitrary relative paths.

At the least, I would like to be able to define a pose alias within an entity (i.e "forearm" instead of <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0 </pose> ).

This requires more thoughts. Do you have suggestions for simplification?
content.html:
This is a valid concern. I think it might be possible to keep the implementation simpler while keeping important functionality: For example, we could:

  • confine frames to a single link, without the possibility of specifying a parent.
  • when declaring a pose, limit the use of frames to the current link (or sibling), instead of arbitrary relative paths.

At the least, I would like to be able to define a pose alias within an entity (i.e "forearm" instead of <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0 </pose> ).

This requires more thoughts. Do you have suggestions for simplification?

content.raw:
This added complexity is my biggest concern about this design. I currently know of two other pieces of software with their own sdformat parsers (dartsim and some IHMC code), and this would make things a bit harder for them. I remember @nkoenig saying that we wanted to avoid the example of Collada in being overly complex.

This isn't a `No` vote, just a concern.
content.html:
This added complexity is my biggest concern about this design. I currently know of two other pieces of software with their own sdformat parsers (dartsim and some IHMC code), and this would make things a bit harder for them. I remember @nkoenig saying that we wanted to avoid the example of Collada in being overly complex.

This isn't a No vote, just a concern.

content.raw: It seems like joint 2 is attached to `l3frame`, not this one. This one is indirectly attached to `j2frame` via `l3frame`, so what's the point of this frame?
content.html: It seems like joint 2 is attached to l3frame, not this one. This one is indirectly attached to j2frame via l3frame, so what's the point of this frame?

content.raw: Of course
content.html: Of course

content.raw:
I like relative paths, especially using ".." as an alias for a parent, or two frames defined in the same file. 
Question: Does it work if model1 and model2 are defined in separate sdf files? 


In your example, the pose

```
#!python
<pose frame="/world/model1/model2/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
```

references a "model1", which could be a problem, if model1 is not installed (or is called "model1_0").

I think the problem only applies to model names, since other elements cannot change name or be split in different files.
content.html:
I like relative paths, especially using ".." as an alias for a parent, or two frames defined in the same file. Question: Does it work if model1 and model2 are defined in separate sdf files?

In your example, the pose

<pose frame="/world/model1/model2/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

references a "model1", which could be a problem, if model1 is not installed (or is called "model1_0").

I think the problem only applies to model names, since other elements cannot change name or be split in different files.

update.title: Sdf_reference_geometry

content.raw:
I've put in the concept of absolute and relative paths to frames, which should resolve this issue.

```
#!xml

<model name="model1">

  <frame name="f_model">
     <!-- Relative to the absolute world path -->
    <pose frame="/world">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </frame>

  <!-- Relative to the current xml level -->
  <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

  <!-- Absolute path, which is equivalent to the above pose.  -->
  <pose frame="/world/model1/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

  <model name="model2">

    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="/world">0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>

    <!-- Relative -->
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <!-- Absolute -->
    <pose frame="/world/model1/model2/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <!-- Pose relative to model2 -->
        <pose frame="../f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>

  <model name="model3">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="/world">2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="../f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>   
</model>
```
content.html:
I've put in the concept of absolute and relative paths to frames, which should resolve this issue.

<model name="model1">

  <frame name="f_model">
     <!-- Relative to the absolute world path -->
    <pose frame="/world">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </frame>

  <!-- Relative to the current xml level -->
  <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

  <!-- Absolute path, which is equivalent to the above pose.  -->
  <pose frame="/world/model1/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

  <model name="model2">

    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="/world">0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>

    <!-- Relative -->
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <!-- Absolute -->
    <pose frame="/world/model1/model2/f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <!-- Pose relative to model2 -->
        <pose frame="../f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>

  <model name="model3">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="/world">2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="../f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>   
</model>

content.raw:
You are right: there needs to be scoping rules. Frames could have their model name as a scope (unless they are global frames). This could take care of nesting.
But I think we decided against further scoping, pointing out that the frame graph was independent of the mode / link graph.
content.html: You are right: there needs to be scoping rules. Frames could have their model name as a scope (unless they are global frames). This could take care of nesting. But I think we decided against further scoping, pointing out that the frame graph was independent of the mode / link graph.

content.raw: Maybe we could ask @dljsjr and @jespersmith for some feedback on this design document, since I believe they are familiar with the use of reference frames in their simulator (SCS) and also with Gazebo and SDFormat.
content.html: Maybe we could ask @dljsjr and @jespersmith for some feedback on this design document, since I believe they are familiar with the use of reference frames in their simulator (SCS) and also with Gazebo and SDFormat.
